_header: O ye creatures that be reasonable
Note: For other MSS that have a Prologue of five stanzas see 4107.
Bibliographic Ghosts: Cambridge MA, Harvard University, Houghton Library, Eng. 752 [olim *27282. 67.10; priorAshburnham 131]: A single stanza (22) inserted in the text of Lydgate’s Troy Book. [Thus Bergen, but the lines he cites do not appear on f. 44 in this MS.]
_description: John Lydgate, ‘Dance of Macabre’ — seventy-three 8-line stanzas

Bod686.First Lines:
Hec scriptura deus pompam luxumque relegatInque choris nostris
                    ducere festa monetCreatures ye þat be resonableThe life desiryng
                    whiche is eternal…
Bod686.Last Lines:
…Sit Iugiter cuncti sapientes vinere certentVt velut inferni
                    sit metuenda palus
Bod686.Attributed Title:
Here begynneþ a tretis of the daunce of Poulys otherweyes called
                    Makabre (f. 209); Here endeth a tretis of the daunce of Poules otherweyes called
                    Makabre (at the end)

OxfCCC237.First Lines:
O creatures ȝe þat ben resonabylleThe lyfe desyring
                    wheche ys eternall…
OxfCCC237.Last Lines:
…To eschewe peyne & come to gloryWhele ys hym that so may
                    at þe laste

BLCottVesAXXV.First Lines:
O ye creatures that be ResonableThe lyffe desyring that be
                    naturall…
BLCottVesAXXV.Last Lines:
…Bewaire be tyme & labour for mercy in stantlyWho tresteth
                    most there stait shall oftymes be begyled
BLCottVesAXXV.Editions:
Böddeker,  Karl. 
             “Englische Lieder und Balladen aus dem 16 Jahrhundert, nach einer
                Handschrift der Cottonianischen Bibliothek des Britischen Museums.” 
             Jahrbuch für romanische und englische Sprache- und
                Literatur
         15 (or n.f. 3) (1876): 92-129 [2590 (3)]: 115.

BLLan699.First Lines:
O Creatures that been resonableThe liff desiryng which is
                    eternall…
BLLan699.Last Lines:
…And vse vertu prayer & almesse deedeAnd than I dar sey ye
                    shal doon the bettir
BLLan699.Note: Folio number reflects to the most recent foliation.
BLLan699.Editions:
Warren,  Florence,  and  Beatrice White, eds.  
             The Dance of Death.
EETS
         o.s. 181 (1931); repr. 1971: 7-77.

Lincoln129.First Lines:
O Creaturs that been resounnablethe lyff desiryng which is
                    eternallye may see heer doctryne ful notableYour lyff to leede the
                    which that is mortall…
Lincoln129.Last Lines:
…and vse vertu prayeer & almesse deedeand than I dar say
                    ye shal do the bettir
Lincoln129.Editions:
Warren,  Florence,  and  Beatrice White, eds.  
             The Dance of Death.
EETS
         o.s. 181 (1931); repr. 1971: 7-77.
